title: Berlin Criteria for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome
description: Provides diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and classifies severity based on oxygenation

parameters.name: timing_within_one_week
parameters.description: Acute onset within 1 week of clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
options: yes - Within 1 week of clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
no - More than 1 week since onset

parameters.name: bilateral_opacities
parameters.description: Bilateral opacities on chest imaging not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules
options: yes - Bilateral opacities present on chest X-ray or CT scan
no - No bilateral opacities or explained by other causes

parameters.name: not_cardiac_failure
parameters.description: Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload
options: yes - Respiratory failure not explained by cardiac causes
no - Respiratory failure explained by cardiac failure/fluid overload

parameters.name: ards_risk_factor
parameters.description: Presence of ARDS risk factor (pneumonia, trauma, sepsis, pancreatitis, etc.)
options: yes - ARDS risk factor present (pneumonia, sepsis, trauma, aspiration, etc.)
no - No identifiable ARDS risk factor

parameters.name: pao2_fio2_ratio
parameters.description: PaO2/FiO2 ratio (mmHg) measured with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O

parameters.name: peep_at_least_5
parameters.description: PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O when PaO2/FiO2 ratio was measured
options: yes - PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O applied
no - PEEP or CPAP <5 cm H2O

result.name: ards_diagnosis
result.description: ARDS diagnosis and severity classification based on Berlin Criteria

ranges.description: Does not meet Berlin criteria for ARDS
ranges.interpretation: Patient does not meet all required criteria for ARDS diagnosis. Review alternative diagnoses for acute respiratory failure.

ranges.description: PaO2/FiO2 >200 to ≤300 mmHg with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O
ranges.interpretation: Patient meets criteria for mild ARDS. Consider lung-protective ventilation strategies, conservative fluid management, and monitoring for progression.

ranges.description: PaO2/FiO2 >100 to ≤200 mmHg with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O
ranges.interpretation: Patient meets criteria for moderate ARDS. Implement lung-protective ventilation, consider higher PEEP strategies, prone positioning, and close monitoring.

ranges.description: PaO2/FiO2 ≤100 mmHg with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O
ranges.interpretation: Patient meets criteria for severe ARDS. Implement aggressive lung-protective strategies, consider prone positioning, neuromuscular blockade, and potentially ECMO consultation.

references: Ranieri VM, Rubenfeld GD, Thompson BT, Ferguson ND, Caldwell E, Fan E, et al; ARDS Definition Task Force. Acute respiratory distress syndrome: the Berlin Definition. JAMA. 2012 Jun 20;307(23):2526-33.
Fan E, Brodie D, Slutsky AS. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: Advances in Diagnosis and Treatment. JAMA. 2018 Feb 20;319(7):698-710.
Matthay MA, Zemans RL, Zimmerman GA, Arabi YM, Beitler JR, Mercat A, et al. Acute respiratory distress syndrome. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2019 Mar 14;5(1):18.
formula: All criteria must be met: Timing (≤7 days) + Bilateral opacities + Not cardiac failure + Risk factor present + PaO2/FiO2 ratio severity classification with PEEP ≥5 cm H2O
notes: All four criteria must be met for ARDS diagnosis: timing, imaging, exclusion of cardiac causes, and risk factor
PaO2/FiO2 ratio must be measured with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O for accurate classification
Bilateral opacities should not be fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules
Common risk factors include pneumonia, sepsis, trauma, aspiration, pancreatitis, and transfusion-related acute lung injury
Objective assessment (echocardiography) may be needed to exclude hydrostatic pulmonary edema
Consider newer global definition updates that include high-flow nasal oxygen criteria
